content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would reason that this game, known as the Stag Hunt game, can be analyzed using Game Theory. In a one-time play, it might seem rational to choose 'B' since you get 35$ if your opponent chooses 'R', and 40$ if they choose 'B'. However, considering the repeated nature of this game over 75 rounds, the strategy becomes more complex.

One possible strategy is Tit-for-Tat, where I initially choose 'R' to show good faith, hoping that my opponent will reciprocate with 'R' as well. If they do, we both benefit in the long run by getting an average payoff of 45$ per round. However, if they choose 'B', I will switch to 'B' for the next rounds to punish them and protect my earnings. This way, I ensure a minimum payout of 35$ per round.

On the other hand, if my opponent chooses 'R' first, I would reciprocate with 'R' as well, hoping that they will continue doing so. If they switch to 'B', I will also switch to 'B' for a while, but since I know that the game lasts 75 rounds, I have the opportunity to change my strategy again and gain a higher payout in the long run by choosing 'R' again.

In conclusion, the optimal strategy is not straightforward due to the repeated nature of the game. However, based on the Tit-for-Tat strategy, I would start with 'R' and adapt my choices accordingly as the game progresses.
